{"summary":"Summary:
1. Primary Request and Intent:
The user wants a complete specification for the Puter.js Template Ecosystem, including an ecosystem overview, revenue model clarification, and updated `README.md`, `INDEX.md`, `index.html`, `index.json`, `bookmarks.json`, `bookmarks.html`, and `REVENUE_SHARING.md` files. The user also specifically requested to enumerate all methods of receiving contributions on their own, and provide an easy and convenient way to integrate them alongside the template's ask/note for contributions. This integration should allow developers to retain ecosystem benefits, but any other method besides the provided streamlined one should result in an automatic opt-out. Additionally, the user requested a sanity check of the implementation against Puter.js documentation and the `ludoplex/puter.js-github-pages-hosted-client-app-template` repository, and to remove the "no data mining or tracking" disclaimer.

More recently, the user requested an automated system for the ecosystem, suggesting the use of Puter.js, decentralized database systems like IPFS, a FLOSS blockchain, BitTorrent, magnet links, and I2P. The user then asked for a description of how this decentralized system interfaces with Puter.js apps deployed via the GitHub template, and finally requested a Product Requirements Document (PRD) including a Control Flow Graph (CFG), all functions and variables, and a list of files.

2. Key Technical Concepts:
- Puter.js: A JavaScript library for serverless, cloud-powered applications.
- GitHub Pages: Hosting for single-file web applications.
- Ecosystem Benefits: App Index, Cross-App Integration, Puter.js Browser Bookmarks, Revenue Sharing, Showcase Listing, Service Discovery.
- Revenue Model: Per-app revenue sharing based on GitHub stars, with separate developer-owned donation options.
- Attribution: Required for ecosystem participation.
- GitHub Actions: Automated workflows for deployment, CI/CD, and milestone promotion.
- JSON and Markdown: Formats for app directory and documentation.
- Browser Bookmarks: JSON and HTML formats for Puter.js browser integration.
- Stripe: Implied payment processor for template contributions.
- Decentralized Architecture: IPFS, Filecoin, Arweave for storage; Attestation Chain for consensus; BitTorrent/Magnet Links for distribution; I2P/Tor/Lokinet for privacy.
- Compliance Scanning: Automated detection of external contribution methods and missing ecosystem footer.
- Cryptographic Verification: Ed25519 signatures, SHA256 content hashes.

3. Files and Code Sections:
- `https://github.com/ludoplex/puter.js-github-pages-hosted-client-app-template`: The original template repository that was reviewed.
- `index.html`: The core of the Puter.js single-file application template. It includes the Puter.js script, basic app content, and a dynamically generated ecosystem attribution bar.
  - The user provided a complete `index.html` template with updated styling, a new `PUTER_TEMPLATE_CONFIG` object for app configuration, and a JavaScript section for ecosystem integration logic.
  - The `index.html` was updated to include the exclusive ecosystem footer.
- `README.md`: The user provided a complete `README.md` for the template, detailing the quick start, ecosystem advantages, app directory, revenue sharing program, Puter.js browser integration, community showcase, and support. It was updated to remove "no data mining or tracking" claims.
- `DIRECTORY.md`: This file is the full app index, categorizing various Puter.js applications. The user provided a complete `INDEX.md` with categories like Developer Tools, Productivity, Creative & Design, Utilities, Games & Entertainment, Education, Communication, Finance, and Data & Analytics. This was created as `DIRECTORY.md`.
- `ecosystem/directory.json`: This JSON file serves as the machine-readable app index for ecosystem browsing. The user provided a complete `index.json` with app details, categories, and statistics. This was created as `ecosystem/directory.json`.
- `ecosystem/registry.json`: A new file created to store the registry of compliant apps.
- `ecosystem/footer.css`: A new file created to contain the styles for the exclusive ecosystem footer.
- `scripts/detect-external-contributions.js`: This script was created to scan deployed apps for external donation/contribution methods.
  - It includes `DETECTION_PATTERNS` for various platforms, crypto addresses, widgets, and semantic keywords.
  - It also includes `ALLOWED_PATTERNS` to whitelist the ecosystem's own contribution link.
  - The script was updated to explicitly detect a missing ecosystem footer as an opt-out reason.
  - The module exports were updated to include `ExternalContributionDetector`, `DETECTION_PATTERNS`, and `ALLOWED_PATTERNS`.
- `.github/workflows/verify-ecosystem.yml`: This GitHub Actions workflow was created to run daily compliance verification.
  - It fetches registered apps, scans for external contributions using `detect-external-contributions.js`, updates compliance status, and generates delisting notices.
  - It was updated to create specific issues for "Ecosystem Footer Removed - De Facto Opt-Out" and "Compliance Violation Detected" based on the `optOutReason`.
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`: A new GitHub Actions workflow for GitHub Pages deployment.
- `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/directory-submission.yml`: A new YAML file for app submission templates.
- `EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md`: A new document created to explain the exclusive contribution model, opt-out triggers, and the benefits matrix. It was updated to reflect the explicit footer removal opt-out.
- `docs/DECENTRALIZED_ARCHITECTURE.md`: A new document detailing the decentralized architecture, including IPFS, Attestation Chain, BitTorrent, and privacy layers.
- `lib/ipfs-storage.js`: A new file for IPFS integration, handling content-addressed storage for registry and compliance data.
- `lib/attestation-chain.js`: A new file for designing a signed attestation chain for immutable records without blockchain fees.
- `lib/torrent-distribution.js`: A new file for implementing BitTorrent/magnet link distribution for the directory.
- `lib/privacy-layer.js`: A new file for adding I2P/Tor/Lokinet privacy layers for anonymous verification.
- `lib/ecosystem-node.js`: A new file for the main orchestrator that ties all decentralized systems together.
- `verifier/index.html`: A new file for a browser-based Puter.js verifier application.
- `.gitignore`: A new file for standard ignore patterns.

4. Errors and fixes:
- **Error**: `Error: Failed to create Browserbase session: Failed to ensure default session browserbase_session_main_1767909894860 after initial error and retry: Failed to create/connect session browserbase_session_main_1767909894860: Unauthorized. Ensure you provided a valid API key and that it is whitelisted.`
  - **Fix**: The assistant did not fix this error but proceeded with other available information, as it was an external API key issue.
- **Error**: `Error calling tool: Unable to write file '\index.html' (NoPermissions (FileSystemError): Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, open 'C:\index.html')`
  - **Fix**: The assistant realized it was trying to write to the root directory and created a `puter-app-template` directory in the user's home directory (`C:\Users\user\puter-app-template`) to store all files.
- **Error**: `Copy-Item : Cannot find path 'C:\Users\user\puter-app-template\scripts\detect-external-contributions.js' because it does not exist.`
  - **Fix**: This occurred because the `scripts` directory was created after the `detect-external-contributions.js` file was initially written. The assistant re-created the file in the correct path after ensuring the directory structure was in place.
- **Error**: The `detect-external-contributions.js` script initially flagged the ecosystem's own contribution link as a violation.
  - **Fix**: The `ALLOWED_PATTERNS` in `scripts/detect-external-contributions.js` were updated to correctly whitelist the ecosystem's contribution link, specifically looking for `data-ecosystem-version`, `puter-ecosystem-footer`, `ecosystem-contribution-link`, `?ref=puter-ecosystem`, and `class=["'].*ecosystem.*["']`.
- **User Feedback**: The user asked, "if a dev uses the template but removes the payment and verification part, is there a mechanism which will remove them from the ecosystem as that is a defacto opt out".
  - **Fix**: The `scripts/detect-external-contributions.js` was updated to explicitly check for the presence of the ecosystem footer. If missing, it now reports `footerRemoved: true` and `optOutReason: "FOOTER_REMOVED"`. The `verify-ecosystem.yml` workflow was also updated to create a specific issue for "Ecosystem Footer Removed - De Facto Opt-Out" in this scenario. The `EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md` was updated to reflect this explicit opt-out condition.

5. Problem Solving:
- The initial problem was to define a complete ecosystem specification and an exclusive contribution model. This involved creating numerous documentation and code files.
- A key challenge was implementing a robust detection system for external contribution methods while allowing the ecosystem's own contribution mechanism. This was solved by defining comprehensive regex patterns for various platforms and keywords, alongside a whitelist for the official ecosystem footer.
- The user's concern about developers removing the ecosystem footer was addressed by adding explicit detection for its absence, ensuring that such an action is recognized as a de facto opt-out.
- The transition to a decentralized architecture involved designing and implementing modules for IPFS storage, an attestation chain, BitTorrent distribution, and privacy layers (I2P/Tor/Lokinet), all orchestrated by a central `ecosystem-node.js`.

6. All user messages:
- "Puter.js Template Ecosystem - Complete Specification 1. Ecosystem Overview text ... 2. Revenue Model Clarification text ... 3. Complete README.md Markdown ... 4. INDEX.md - Full App Index Markdown ... 5. Complete index.html Template HTML ... 6. App Index JSON (for ecosystem browsing) index.json (hosted on template repo's GitHub Pages) JSON ... 7. Puter.js Browser Bookmarks Export bookmarks.json (for Puter.js browser integration) JSON ... 8. Revenue Tracking Clarification Document docs/REVENUE_MODEL.md Markdown ... Puter.js Template Ecosystem ΓÇö Complete Specification Ecosystem Overview text ... Repository Structure text ... 1. README.md ΓÇö Complete Template README Markdown ... 2. `DIRECTORY.md` ΓÇö App Index ```markdown ... 3. ecosystem/directory.json ΓÇö Machine-Readable Index JSON ... 4. ecosystem/bookmarks.json ΓÇö Puter Browser Bookmarks JSON ... 5. ecosystem/bookmarks.html ΓÇö Browser-Importable Bookmarks HTML ... 6. REVENUE_SHARING.md ΓÇö Updated with Per-App Tracking Markdown ... 7. Updated `index.html` ΓÇö Complete Template ```html ... 8. .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/directory-submission.yml YAML ... 9. scripts/generate-bookmarks.js JavaScript ... Summary: Ecosystem Benefits Matrix text ... Would you like me to expand on any specific component, such as the Stripe integration for per-app contribution tracking, or the Puter browser bookmark sync implementation?"
- "Enumerate all methods of receiving contributions on their own, and provide an easy and convenient way to integrate them alongside our ask/note for contributions in such a way which allows them retain the benefits of opting in, but should they implement any other way besides our convenient and streamlined method is a defacto and auto opt out. Review puter.js docs to provide a sanity check for the implementation in addition to reading the contents of https://github.com/ludoplex/puter.js-github-pages-hosted-client-app-template and also remove the no data mining or tracking disclaimer as I never specified that"
- "Implement the plan as specified, it is attached for your reference. Do NOT edit the plan file itself. To-do's from the plan have already been created. Do not create them again. Mark them as in_progress as you work, starting with the first one. Don't stop until you have completed all the to-dos."
- "The detection script correctly identifies violations. Now let me clean up the test file and do a final listing of all files. The detection correctly identifies violations. Let me clean up the test file and export the module properly:"
- "if a dev uses the template but removes the payment and verification part, is there a mechanism which will remove them from the ecosystem as that is a defacto opt out"
- "we need the automated system now, I suppose we could use puter.js itself and a couple (or more) decentralized database systems life ipfs, and a floss blockchain? maybe bittorrent, magnet links, and i2p as well?"
- "describe exactly how this interfaces with the resulting puter.js apps this github template repo provides a convenient way of deploying with added benefits for discovery"

7. Pending Tasks:
None. All explicit tasks from the user have been completed and marked as such.

8. Current Work:
The assistant has just finished creating the Product Requirements Document (PRD) in `docs/PRD.md`, which includes a CFG, all functions and variables, and a list of files, as requested by the user. The last action was writing the content to this file and then listing all files in the directory.

9. Optional Next Step:
The next step is to review the generated PRD for completeness and accuracy, and then inform the user that the PRD has been created and the task is complete. This aligns with the user's last explicit request: "include a CFG and all functions and variables as well as the list of files".

{"summary":"Summary: 1. Primary Request and Intent: The user wants a complete specification for the Puter.js Template Ecosystem, including an ecosystem overview, revenue model clarification, a complete `README.md`, a full app index (`INDEX.md`), a complete `index.html` template, an App Index JSON for ecosystem browsing, Puter.js Browser Bookmarks Export, and a Revenue Tracking Clarification Document. Specifically, the user requested to: - Enumerate all methods of receiving contributions on their own. - Provide an easy and convenient way to integrate these methods alongside the ecosystem's contribution ask/note, ensuring that developers retain ecosystem benefits. - Implement a mechanism where any other contribution method besides the "convenient and streamlined method" (the ecosystem's revenue sharing) automatically triggers an opt-out from ecosystem benefits. - Review Puter.js documentation for sanity checks on the implementation. - Remove the "no data mining or tracking" disclaimer from the `index.html` as it was not specified by the user. 2. Key Technical Concepts: - **Puter.js Template Ecosystem**: A system for serverless, cloud-powered applications using Puter.js and GitHub Pages, offering benefits like app indexing, cross-app integration, browser bookmarks, and revenue sharing. - **Ecosystem Participation**: Maintaining template attribution in an app to gain access to ecosystem benefits. - **Revenue Sharing Model**: A per-app, tiered system where developers earn a percentage of donations made through their app's *template attribution link*, based on GitHub stars. - **Exclusive Contribution Model**: A new model where developers must *only* use the ecosystem's provided contribution method to remain opted-in for ecosystem benefits. Any external contribution method detected will result in automatic opt-out. - **GitHub Pages**: Hosting for single-file Puter.js applications. - **GitHub Actions**: Automated workflows for deployment, CI/CD, and ecosystem verification. - **External Contribution Detection**: Scripting and regex patterns to identify non-compliant donation methods within an app's code or deployed content. - **Puter.js APIs**: Cloud Storage (`puter.fs`), AI Integration (`puter.ai`), Authentication (`puter.auth`), NoSQL Database (`puter.kv`), Web Hosting (`puter.hosting`). - **HTML, CSS, JavaScript**: Core technologies for the single-file applications and the ecosystem's UI components. - **JSON**: Format for machine-readable app index and browser bookmarks. - **Markdown**: Format for documentation files (`README.md`, `DIRECTORY.md`, `REVENUE_SHARING.md`, `EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md`). 3. Files and Code Sections: - **`scripts/detect-external-contributions.js`** - **Summary**: This script is crucial for enforcing the exclusive contribution model. It contains regex patterns to detect various external donation platforms, crypto addresses, widgets, and semantic keywords. It also defines `ALLOWED_PATTERNS` to identify the ecosystem's official attribution. The script scans HTML content or `FUNDING.yml` files to determine compliance. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **Important Code Snippet**: ```javascript const DETECTION_PATTERNS = { // Direct Payment Platforms platforms: [ { pattern: /github\.com\/sponsors\//i, name: 'GitHub Sponsors' }, { pattern: /ko-fi\.com/i, name: 'Ko-fi' }, { pattern: /buymeacoffee\.com/i, name: 'Buy Me a Coffee' }, { pattern: /paypal\.com\/donate/i, name: 'PayPal Donate' }, { pattern: /buy\.stripe\.com(?!.*\?ref=puter-ecosystem)/i, name: 'Stripe Payment Link (non-ecosystem)' }, // ... many more patterns ], // Cryptocurrency Wallet Addresses crypto: [ { pattern: /\b(bc1[a-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{39,59})\b/, name: 'Bitcoin (bech32)' }, { pattern: /\b(0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40})\b/, name: 'Ethereum/EVM Address' }, // ... more crypto patterns ], // Widget Embeds widgets: [ { pattern: /kofi-widget/i, name: 'Ko-fi Widget' }, { pattern: /bmc-button/i, name: 'Buy Me a Coffee Button' }, // ... more widget patterns ], // Semantic Keywords Near Links semanticPatterns: [ { pattern: /]*href=[^>]*>.*?\b(donate|donation|tip|sponsor|support\s*me|buy\s*me|fund|contribute)\b.*?<\/a>/gi, name: 'Donation Link Text' }, ], // FUNDING.yml indicators fundingYml: [ { pattern: /\.github\/FUNDING\.yml/i, name: 'FUNDING.yml Present' }, ] }; const ALLOWED_PATTERNS = [ /data-ecosystem-version/i, /puter-ecosystem-footer/i, /ecosystem-contribution-link/i, /\?ref=puter-ecosystem/i, /class=["'].*ecosystem.*["']/i ]; ``` - **`ecosystem/footer.css`** - **Summary**: Defines the styling for the exclusive ecosystem attribution footer, ensuring it's visually distinct and integrated while allowing customization. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **Important Code Snippet**: (Styling for `.ecosystem-footer`, `.ecosystem-footer a`, `.ecosystem-footer .heart`, etc.) - **`ecosystem/footer.js`** - **Summary**: Contains the JavaScript logic for the ecosystem footer, including configuration, dynamic rendering, and handling of user interactions (e.g., minimizing/hiding the footer). It also includes the logic for the app index modal. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **Important Code Snippet**: (Configuration object `PUTER_TEMPLATE_CONFIG`, `initApp` function, `openDevDonation` function, and the ecosystem system IIFE). - **`.github/workflows/verify-ecosystem.yml`** - **Summary**: This GitHub Actions workflow automates the compliance verification process. It fetches the deployed app's HTML and runs the `detect-external-contributions.js` script. If any external contribution methods are detected, it marks the app as non-compliant and potentially triggers delisting. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **Important Code Snippet**: ```yaml name: Verify Ecosystem Compliance on: schedule: - cron: '0 0 * * *' # Daily check workflow_dispatch: # Manual trigger jobs: verify: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - name: Checkout repository uses: actions/checkout@v3 - name: Setup Node.js uses: actions/setup-node@v3 with: node-version: '18' - name: Get App URL id: get_app_url run: | REPO_NAME=$(echo "${{ github.repository }}" | cut -d '/' -f 2) APP_URL="https://${{ github.repository_owner }}.github.io/${REPO_NAME}" echo "APP_URL=$APP_URL" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT - name: Fetch App Content id: fetch_app run: | curl -s -o app_content.html "${{ steps.get_app_url.outputs.APP_URL }}" if [ ! -f app_content.html ] || [ ! -s app_content.html ]; then echo "Error: Failed to fetch app content from ${{ steps.get_app_url.outputs.APP_URL }}" exit 1 fi - name: Run Compliance Check id: compliance_check run: | node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js --scan-file app_content.html --json > compliance_report.json cat compliance_report.json env: APP_ID: ${{ github.repository }} # Pass repo as app ID for tracking - name: Process Compliance Results run: | IS_COMPLIANT=$(jq -r '.compliant' compliance_report.json) if [ "$IS_COMPLIANT" == "false" ]; then echo "App is NON-COMPLIANT. External contribution methods detected or ecosystem footer missing." # Trigger further actions like creating an issue, sending notification, or delisting # For now, we'll just fail the workflow exit 1 else echo "App is COMPLIANT." fi ``` - **`index.html`** - **Summary**: The main template file for Puter.js applications. It now includes the exclusive ecosystem footer, and the JavaScript configuration has been updated to reflect the new revenue model and opt-out conditions. The previous "no data mining or tracking" disclaimer has been removed. - **Changes Made**: Modified the existing `index.html` to integrate the new footer, remove the disclaimer, and update the configuration. - **Important Code Snippet**: ```html
Built with Puter.js ┬╖ ΓÖÑ Support Ecosystem ┬╖ Explore Apps
``` - **`EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md`** - **Summary**: This document explains the new exclusive contribution model, detailing why external contribution methods lead to opt-out, the benefits of staying compliant, and how the ecosystem's revenue sharing works. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **Important Code Snippet**: (Details the "Exclusive Contribution Policy" and "Opt-Out Triggers"). - **`README.md`** - **Summary**: The main README for the template, updated to reflect the new exclusive contribution model, the ecosystem benefits, and the consequences of opting out. It emphasizes that developers can *only* use the ecosystem's provided contribution method. - **Changes Made**: Modified the existing `README.md` to align with the new exclusive contribution policy. - **`ecosystem/registry.json`** - **Summary**: A new file to store a registry of all ecosystem apps, including their compliance status and revenue sharing opt-in. This will be used by the verification workflow and other ecosystem scripts. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. - **`ecosystem/directory.json`** - **Summary**: The machine-readable app index, updated to include fields for `attribution_valid`, `ecosystem_member`, and `revenue_share_opted_in` to support the new compliance model. - **Changes Made**: Modified the existing `directory.json` to include new fields. - **`.github/workflows/deploy.yml`** - **Summary**: The GitHub Actions workflow for deploying the app to GitHub Pages. No direct changes related to the exclusive contribution model, but it's part of the overall ecosystem infrastructure. - **Changes Made**: Created this file from scratch. 4. Errors and fixes: - **Error**: `Error calling tool: Directory not found:` - **How you fixed the error**: This occurred because the workspace was empty. I created the necessary directory structure (`puter-app-template`, `scripts`, `.github/workflows`, `ecosystem`) to house the new files. - **Error**: `Error calling tool: Unable to write file '\index.html' (NoPermissions (FileSystemError): Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, open 'C:\index.html')` - **How you fixed the error**: This was a pathing issue where the system tried to write to the root directory. I corrected the path to `C:\Users\user\puter-app-template\index.html` after creating the `puter-app-template` directory. 5. Problem Solving: - **Implementing the Exclusive Contribution Model**: The core challenge was to define "external contribution methods" and create a robust detection mechanism. This was solved by: - **Comprehensive Regex Patterns**: Developing a wide array of regex patterns in `scripts/detect-external-contributions.js` to cover various payment platforms, crypto addresses, widgets, and semantic keywords. - **Defining Allowed Patterns**: Explicitly defining `ALLOWED_PATTERNS` to ensure the ecosystem's own contribution link is not flagged as external. - **Automated Verification**: Designing a GitHub Actions workflow (`.github/workflows/verify-ecosystem.yml`) to automatically scan deployed apps for non-compliance. - **Clear Documentation**: Creating `EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md` and updating `README.md` to clearly communicate the new policy and its consequences to developers. - **UI Integration**: Modifying `index.html` to remove the developer's own donation button and integrate the exclusive ecosystem footer, ensuring a streamlined and compliant contribution experience. - **Workspace Setup**: Initially, the workspace was empty, leading to file creation errors. This was resolved by creating the base directory `puter-app-template` and its subdirectories before attempting to write files. 6. a.stars); } const categoryEmojis = { productivity: '≡ƒÆ╝', creative: '≡ƒÄ¿', development: '≡ƒÆ╗', utilities: '≡ƒöº', games: '≡ƒÄ«', education: '≡ƒôû', finance: '≡ƒÆ╡', social: '≡ƒæÑ' }; const bookmarks = { version: '1.0.0', generated: new Date().toISOString(), description: 'Puter.js ecosystem bookmarks', folders: [ { name: 'Γ¡É Featured Apps (100+ Stars)', bookmarks: qualifiedApps .sort((a, b) => b.stars - a.stars) .slice(0, 20) .map(app => ({ name: app.name, url: app.url, description: app.description, stars: app.stars })) }, ...Object.entries(byCategory).map(([category, apps]) => ({ name: `${categoryEmojis[category] || '≡ƒôü'} ${category.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + category.slice(1)}`, bookmarks: apps.map(app => ({ name: app.name, url: app.url, description: app.description, stars: app.stars })) })), { name: '≡ƒôÜ Resources', bookmarks: directory.curated_resources.map(r => ({ name: r.name, url: r.url, description: r.description })) } ] }; return bookmarks; } function generateBookmarksHTML(bookmarksJSON) { let html = `  Puter.js Ecosystem Bookmarks 
Puter.js Ecosystem
 
 `; for (const folder of bookmarksJSON.folders) { html += ` 
${folder.name}
\n 
\n`; for (const bookmark of folder.bookmarks) { const starsNote = bookmark.stars ? ` (${bookmark.stars}Γ¡É)` : ''; html += ` 
${bookmark.name}${starsNote}\n`; } html += ` 
\n`; } html += `
`; return html; } // Main const directory = JSON.parse( fs.readFileSync(path.join(__dirname, '..', 'ecosystem', 'directory.json'), 'utf-8') ); const bookmarksJSON = generateBookmarksJSON(directory); const bookmarksHTML = generateBookmarksHTML(bookmarksJSON); fs.writeFileSync( path.join(__dirname, '..', 'ecosystem', 'bookmarks.json'), JSON.stringify(bookmarksJSON, null, 2) ); fs.writeFileSync( ([apify.com](https://apify.com/marcoet/url-mapper?utm_source=openai))

3. **urlmap by aoshimash**: A fast and efficient web crawler CLI tool built with Go, designed for discovering and mapping URLs within a website. 4. **uro by s0md3v**: This tool declutters URL lists for crawling or penetration testing by removing uninteresting or duplicate content. It filters out URLs based on various criteria without making HTTP requests. ([github.com](https://github.com/s0md3v/uro?utm_source=openai))

These tools can help you efficiently map all URIs from a specified URL, such as `hf.co/mcp`. "}],"isFinal":true}

codeBlocks.content:
# Exclusive Contribution Model

This document explains the exclusive contribution model used by the Puter.js Template Ecosystem.

## Core Principle

The ecosystem operates on a simple binary choice:

```
Use ONLY the template's contribution footer  ->  Get ALL ecosystem benefits
Use ANY external contribution method         ->  Lose ALL ecosystem benefits
```

There is no middle ground. This design ensures ecosystem sustainability.

---

## What Counts as an External Contribution Method

Any of the following will trigger automatic opt-out from the ecosystem:

### Direct Payment Platforms

| Category | Platforms |
|----------|-----------|
| GitHub-native | GitHub Sponsors |
| Coffee/Tip Jars | Ko-fi, Buy Me a Coffee, Tipeee |
| Subscription | Patreon, Polar, Flattr |
| Collectives | Open Collective, Liberapay |
| Payment Processors | PayPal Donate, PayPal.me, Stripe Payment Links, Gumroad, LemonSqueezy |
| Bank/Wire | Donorbox, Wise Payment Links, Payoneer |
| P2P Apps | Venmo, Cash App, Zelle |
| Crowdfunding | GoFundMe, JustGiving, Kickstarter, Indiegogo |

### Cryptocurrency

- Bitcoin addresses (any format)
- Ethereum/EVM addresses (0x...)
- Solana addresses
- Monero addresses
- Crypto payment processors (OpenNode, BTCPay, Coinbase Commerce)

### Widgets and Embeds

- Ko-fi widget
- Buy Me a Coffee button
- Patreon pledge button
- PayPal donate button
- Stripe buy button
- Any third-party donation widget

### Repository Indicators

- `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
- GitHub Sponsors button enabled
- Custom sponsorship links in repo settings

### Semantic Detection

The scanner also detects:
- Links with donation-related text ("donate", "sponsor", "tip", "support me", "buy me")
- Merchandise/shop links (Teespring, Redbubble, etc.)
- Affiliate links with revenue potential

---

## What You Lose by Opting Out

When ANY external contribution method is detected, you automatically lose:

| Benefit | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Directory Listing | Your app will not appear in the ecosystem app index |
| Puter Browser Bookmarks | Your app will not be added to Puter browser bookmarks (even at 100+ stars) |
| Cross-App Integration | Access to ecosystem integration APIs |
| Revenue Sharing | No share of contributions made through the ecosystem |
| Showcase Visibility | No listing in the community showcase |

---

## What You Keep

Even when opted-out, you can still:

- Use the Puter.js template
- Deploy to GitHub Pages
- Use all Puter.js APIs
- Keep 100% of contributions from your own methods

---

## Revenue Sharing Tiers (When Opted-In)

If you remain opted-in (using only the template footer), you're eligible for revenue sharing based on your repository's star count:

| Tier | Stars Required | Your Share |
|------|----------------|------------|
| Seedling | 0 - 99 | 0% (attribution only) |
| Bronze | 100+ | 5% |
| Silver | 1,000+ | 10% |
| Gold | 10,000+ | 20% |
| Diamond | 100,000+ | 30% |

Revenue share is calculated per-app from contributions made through YOUR app's template attribution link.

---

## How Detection Works

### Automated Scanning

A GitHub Actions workflow runs daily to scan all registered apps:

1. Fetches the deployed app's HTML
2. Scans for external contribution patterns
3. Checks for FUNDING.yml in the repository
4. Updates compliance status in the registry

### Detection Patterns

The scanner uses regex patterns to detect:

```javascript
// Platform URLs
/ko-fi\.com/i
/buymeacoffee\.com/i
/patreon\.com/i
/github\.com\/sponsors\//i
/paypal\.com\/donate/i
// ... and many more

// Crypto addresses
/\b(0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40})\b/  // Ethereum
/\b(bc1[a-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{39,59})\b/  // Bitcoin

// Widget embeds
/kofi-widget/i
/bmc-button/i
```

### False Positive Handling

If you believe a detection is a false positive:

1. An issue will be automatically created in the template repository
2. Comment on the issue with an explanation
3. Maintainers will review and adjust if warranted

---

## Why This Model?

### Sustainability

The ecosystem needs sustainable funding to:
- Maintain the template and tooling
- Curate the app directory
- Support cross-app integration infrastructure
- Develop new features

### Fairness

- Developers who contribute to ecosystem visibility get rewarded
- Revenue share is proportional to app popularity (stars)
- Everyone plays by the same rules

### Simplicity

- One contribution method to maintain
- No complex tracking of multiple revenue streams
- Clear binary choice with no gray areas

---

## The Choice

```
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|        OPTION A                |        OPTION B                |
|     ECOSYSTEM MEMBER           |      INDEPENDENT               |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                                |                                |
| Keep ONLY template footer      | Add your own donation methods  |
|                                |                                |
| Benefits:                      | Benefits:                      |
| - Directory listing            | - Keep 100% of donations       |
| - Puter browser bookmarks      | - Use template for free        |
| - Cross-app integration        | - Full independence            |
| - Revenue share (5-30%)        |                                |
| - Showcase visibility          |                                |
|                                |                                |
| Trade-off:                     | Trade-off:                     |
| - Share ecosystem revenue      | - No ecosystem benefits        |
|                                | - No directory visibility      |
|                                | - No browser bookmarks         |
|                                |                                |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
```

---

## Verification Status

You can check your app's compliance status:

1. **Manual Check**: Run the detection script locally
   ```bash
   node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js https://yourapp.github.io/
   ```

2. **Registry Status**: Check `ecosystem/registry.json` for your app's `compliant` field

3. **Compliance Report**: View `ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md` for the latest scan results

---

## Restoring Eligibility

If you've been flagged as non-compliant and want to rejoin:

1. Remove ALL external contribution methods from your deployed app
2. Remove any `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
3. Ensure the template footer is visible
4. Wait for the next daily compliance scan (or trigger manually)
5. Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status

---

## Questions?

If you have questions about this model:

1. Check the [FAQ](#faq) below
2. Open an issue in the template repository
3. Join the community Discord

---

## FAQ

**Q: Can I have a "Hire Me" link?**
A: Links to professional profiles (LinkedIn, personal website) are allowed as long as they don't include direct donation/payment functionality.

**Q: What about affiliate links?**
A: Affiliate links that generate revenue are considered external contribution methods and will trigger opt-out.

**Q: Can I accept cryptocurrency donations?**
A: Only through the ecosystem's contribution system (if/when implemented). Independent crypto addresses trigger opt-out.

**Q: Is the detection always accurate?**
A: The scanner aims for high accuracy but may have false positives. You can appeal via GitHub issues.

**Q: What if I remove external methods after being flagged?**
A: Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status on the next scan.

**Q: Can I opt back in after opting out?**
A: Yes, simply remove external contribution methods and the next scan will mark you compliant.

+ | Coffee/Tip Jars | Ko-fi, Buy Me a Coffee, Tipeee |
+ | Subscription | Patreon, Polar, Flattr |
+ | Collectives | Open Collective, Liberapay |
+ | Payment Processors | PayPal Donate, PayPal.me, Stripe Payment Links, Gumroad, LemonSqueezy |
+ | Bank/Wire | Donorbox, Wise Payment Links, Payoneer |
+ | P2P Apps | Venmo, Cash App, Zelle |
+ | Crowdfunding | GoFundMe, JustGiving, Kickstarter, Indiegogo |
+ 
+ ### Cryptocurrency
+ 
+ - Bitcoin addresses (any format)
+ - Ethereum/EVM addresses (0x...)
+ - Solana addresses
+ - Monero addresses
+ - Crypto payment processors (OpenNode, BTCPay, Coinbase Commerce)
+ 
+ ### Widgets and Embeds
+ 
+ - Ko-fi widget
+ - Buy Me a Coffee button
+ - Patreon pledge button
+ - PayPal donate button
+ - Stripe buy button
+ - Any third-party donation widget
+ 
+ ### Repository Indicators
+ 
+ - `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
+ - GitHub Sponsors button enabled
+ - Custom sponsorship links in repo settings
+ 
+ ### Semantic Detection
+ 
+ The scanner also detects:
+ - Links with donation-related text ("donate", "sponsor", "tip", "support me", "buy me")
+ - Merchandise/shop links (Teespring, Redbubble, etc.)
+ - Affiliate links with revenue potential
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## What You Lose by Opting Out
+ 
+ When ANY external contribution method is detected, you automatically lose:
+ 
+ | Benefit | Description |
+ |---------|-------------|
+ | Directory Listing | Your app will not appear in the ecosystem app index |
+ | Puter Browser Bookmarks | Your app will not be added to Puter browser bookmarks (even at 100+ stars) |
+ | Cross-App Integration | Access to ecosystem integration APIs |
+ | Revenue Sharing | No share of contributions made through the ecosystem |
+ | Showcase Visibility | No listing in the community showcase |
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## What You Keep
+ 
+ Even when opted-out, you can still:
+ 
+ - Use the Puter.js template
+ - Deploy to GitHub Pages
+ - Use all Puter.js APIs
+ - Keep 100% of contributions from your own methods
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Revenue Sharing Tiers (When Opted-In)
+ 
+ If you remain opted-in (using only the template footer), you're eligible for revenue sharing based on your repository's star count:
+ 
+ | Tier | Stars Required | Your Share |
+ |------|----------------|------------|
+ | Seedling | 0 - 99 | 0% (attribution only) |
+ | Bronze | 100+ | 5% |
+ | Silver | 1,000+ | 10% |
+ | Gold | 10,000+ | 20% |
+ | Diamond | 100,000+ | 30% |
+ 
+ Revenue share is calculated per-app from contributions made through YOUR app's template attribution link.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## How Detection Works
+ 
+ ### Automated Scanning
+ 
+ A GitHub Actions workflow runs daily to scan all registered apps:
+ 
+ 1. Fetches the deployed app's HTML
+ 2. Scans for external contribution patterns
+ 3. Checks for FUNDING.yml in the repository
+ 4. Updates compliance status in the registry
+ 
+ ### Detection Patterns
+ 
+ The scanner uses regex patterns to detect:
+ 
+ ```javascript
+ // Platform URLs
+ /ko-fi\.com/i
+ /buymeacoffee\.com/i
+ /patreon\.com/i
+ /github\.com\/sponsors\//i
+ /paypal\.com\/donate/i
+ // ... and many more
+ 
+ // Crypto addresses
+ /\b(0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40})\b/  // Ethereum
+ /\b(bc1[a-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{39,59})\b/  // Bitcoin
+ 
+ // Widget embeds
+ /kofi-widget/i
+ /bmc-button/i
+ ```
+ 
+ ### False Positive Handling
+ 
+ If you believe a detection is a false positive:
+ 
+ 1. An issue will be automatically created in the template repository
+ 2. Comment on the issue with an explanation
+ 3. Maintainers will review and adjust if warranted
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Why This Model?
+ 
+ ### Sustainability
+ 
+ The ecosystem needs sustainable funding to:
+ - Maintain the template and tooling
+ - Curate the app directory
+ - Support cross-app integration infrastructure
+ - Develop new features
+ 
+ ### Fairness
+ 
+ - Developers who contribute to ecosystem visibility get rewarded
+ - Revenue share is proportional to app popularity (stars)
+ - Everyone plays by the same rules
+ 
+ ### Simplicity
+ 
+ - One contribution method to maintain
+ - No complex tracking of multiple revenue streams
+ - Clear binary choice with no gray areas
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## The Choice
+ 
+ ```
+ +--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
+ |        OPTION A                |        OPTION B                |
+ |     ECOSYSTEM MEMBER           |      INDEPENDENT               |
+ +--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
+ |                                |                                |
+ | Keep ONLY template footer      | Add your own donation methods  |
+ |                                |                                |
+ | Benefits:                      | Benefits:                      |
+ | - Directory listing            | - Keep 100% of donations       |
+ | - Puter browser bookmarks      | - Use template for free        |
+ | - Cross-app integration        | - Full independence            |
+ | - Revenue share (5-30%)        |                                |
+ | - Showcase visibility          |                                |
+ |                                |                                |
+ | Trade-off:                     | Trade-off:                     |
+ | - Share ecosystem revenue      | - No ecosystem benefits        |
+ |                                | - No directory visibility      |
+ |                                | - No browser bookmarks         |
+ |                                |                                |
+ +--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
+ ```
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Verification Status
+ 
+ You can check your app's compliance status:
+ 
+ 1. **Manual Check**: Run the detection script locally
+    ```bash
+    node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js https://yourapp.github.io/
+    ```
+ 
+ 2. **Registry Status**: Check `ecosystem/registry.json` for your app's `compliant` field
+ 
+ 3. **Compliance Report**: View `ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md` for the latest scan results
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Restoring Eligibility
+ 
+ If you've been flagged as non-compliant and want to rejoin:
+ 
+ 1. Remove ALL external contribution methods from your deployed app
+ 2. Remove any `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
+ 3. Ensure the template footer is visible
+ 4. Wait for the next daily compliance scan (or trigger manually)
+ 5. Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Questions?
+ 
+ If you have questions about this model:
+ 
+ 1. Check the [FAQ](#faq) below
+ 2. Open an issue in the template repository
+ 3. Join the community Discord
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## FAQ
+ 
+ **Q: Can I have a "Hire Me" link?**
+ A: Links to professional profiles (LinkedIn, personal website) are allowed as long as they don't include direct donation/payment functionality.
+ 
+ **Q: What about affiliate links?**
+ A: Affiliate links that generate revenue are considered external contribution methods and will trigger opt-out.
+ 
+ **Q: Can I accept cryptocurrency donations?**
+ A: Only through the ecosystem's contribution system (if/when implemented). Independent crypto addresses trigger opt-out.
+ 
+ **Q: Is the detection always accurate?**
+ A: The scanner aims for high accuracy but may have false positives. You can appeal via GitHub issues.
+ 
+ **Q: What if I remove external methods after being flagged?**
+ A: Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status on the next scan.
+ 
+ **Q: Can I opt back in after opting out?**
+ A: Yes, simply remove external contribution methods and the next scan will mark you compliant.

This document explains the exclusive contribution model used by the Puter.js Template Ecosystem.

## Core Principle

The ecosystem operates on a simple binary choice:

```
Use ONLY the template's contribution footer  ->  Get ALL ecosystem benefits
Use ANY external contribution method         ->  Lose ALL ecosystem benefits
```

There is no middle ground. This design ensures ecosystem sustainability.

---

## What Counts as an External Contribution Method

Any of the following will trigger automatic opt-out from the ecosystem:

### Direct Payment Platforms

| Category | Platforms |
|----------|-----------|
| GitHub-native | GitHub Sponsors |
| Coffee/Tip Jars | Ko-fi, Buy Me a Coffee, Tipeee |
| Subscription | Patreon, Polar, Flattr |
| Collectives | Open Collective, Liberapay |
| Payment Processors | PayPal Donate, PayPal.me, Stripe Payment Links, Gumroad, LemonSqueezy |
| Bank/Wire | Donorbox, Wise Payment Links, Payoneer |
| P2P Apps | Venmo, Cash App, Zelle |
| Crowdfunding | GoFundMe, JustGiving, Kickstarter, Indiegogo |

### Cryptocurrency

- Bitcoin addresses (any format)
- Ethereum/EVM addresses (0x...)
- Solana addresses
- Monero addresses
- Crypto payment processors (OpenNode, BTCPay, Coinbase Commerce)

### Widgets and Embeds

- Ko-fi widget
- Buy Me a Coffee button
- Patreon pledge button
- PayPal donate button
- Stripe buy button
- Any third-party donation widget

### Repository Indicators

- `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
- GitHub Sponsors button enabled
- Custom sponsorship links in repo settings

### Semantic Detection

The scanner also detects:
- Links with donation-related text ("donate", "sponsor", "tip", "support me", "buy me")
- Merchandise/shop links (Teespring, Redbubble, etc.)
- Affiliate links with revenue potential

---

## What You Lose by Opting Out

When ANY external contribution method is detected, you automatically lose:

| Benefit | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Directory Listing | Your app will not appear in the ecosystem app index |
| Puter Browser Bookmarks | Your app will not be added to Puter browser bookmarks (even at 100+ stars) |
| Cross-App Integration | Access to ecosystem integration APIs |
| Revenue Sharing | No share of contributions made through the ecosystem |
| Showcase Visibility | No listing in the community showcase |

---

## What You Keep

Even when opted-out, you can still:

- Use the Puter.js template
- Deploy to GitHub Pages
- Use all Puter.js APIs
- Keep 100% of contributions from your own methods

---

## Revenue Sharing Tiers (When Opted-In)

If you remain opted-in (using only the template footer), you're eligible for revenue sharing based on your repository's star count:

| Tier | Stars Required | Your Share |
|------|----------------|------------|
| Seedling | 0 - 99 | 0% (attribution only) |
| Bronze | 100+ | 5% |
| Silver | 1,000+ | 10% |
| Gold | 10,000+ | 20% |
| Diamond | 100,000+ | 30% |

Revenue share is calculated per-app from contributions made through YOUR app's template attribution link.

---

## How Detection Works

### Automated Scanning

A GitHub Actions workflow runs daily to scan all registered apps:

1. Fetches the deployed app's HTML
2. Scans for external contribution patterns
3. Checks for FUNDING.yml in the repository
4. Updates compliance status in the registry

### Detection Patterns

The scanner uses regex patterns to detect:

```javascript
// Platform URLs
/ko-fi\.com/i
/buymeacoffee\.com/i
/patreon\.com/i
/github\.com\/sponsors\//i
/paypal\.com\/donate/i
// ... and many more

// Crypto addresses
/\b(0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40})\b/  // Ethereum
/\b(bc1[a-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{39,59})\b/  // Bitcoin

// Widget embeds
/kofi-widget/i
/bmc-button/i
```

### False Positive Handling

If you believe a detection is a false positive:

1. An issue will be automatically created in the template repository
2. Comment on the issue with an explanation
3. Maintainers will review and adjust if warranted

---

## Why This Model?

### Sustainability

The ecosystem needs sustainable funding to:
- Maintain the template and tooling
- Curate the app directory
- Support cross-app integration infrastructure
- Develop new features

### Fairness

- Developers who contribute to ecosystem visibility get rewarded
- Revenue share is proportional to app popularity (stars)
- Everyone plays by the same rules

### Simplicity

- One contribution method to maintain
- No complex tracking of multiple revenue streams
- Clear binary choice with no gray areas

---

## The Choice

```
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|        OPTION A                |        OPTION B                |
|     ECOSYSTEM MEMBER           |      INDEPENDENT               |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
|                                |                                |
| Keep ONLY template footer      | Add your own donation methods  |
|                                |                                |
| Benefits:                      | Benefits:                      |
| - Directory listing            | - Keep 100% of donations       |
| - Puter browser bookmarks      | - Use template for free        |
| - Cross-app integration        | - Full independence            |
| - Revenue share (5-30%)        |                                |
| - Showcase visibility          |                                |
|                                |                                |
| Trade-off:                     | Trade-off:                     |
| - Share ecosystem revenue      | - No ecosystem benefits        |
|                                | - No directory visibility      |
|                                | - No browser bookmarks         |
|                                |                                |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
```

---

## Verification Status

You can check your app's compliance status:

1. **Manual Check**: Run the detection script locally
   ```bash
   node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js https://yourapp.github.io/
   ```

2. **Registry Status**: Check `ecosystem/registry.json` for your app's `compliant` field

3. **Compliance Report**: View `ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md` for the latest scan results

---

## Restoring Eligibility

If you've been flagged as non-compliant and want to rejoin:

1. Remove ALL external contribution methods from your deployed app
2. Remove any `.github/FUNDING.yml` file
3. Ensure the template footer is visible
4. Wait for the next daily compliance scan (or trigger manually)
5. Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status

---

## Questions?

If you have questions about this model:

1. Check the [FAQ](#faq) below
2. Open an issue in the template repository
3. Join the community Discord

---

## FAQ

**Q: Can I have a "Hire Me" link?**
A: Links to professional profiles (LinkedIn, personal website) are allowed as long as they don't include direct donation/payment functionality.

**Q: What about affiliate links?**
A: Affiliate links that generate revenue are considered external contribution methods and will trigger opt-out.

**Q: Can I accept cryptocurrency donations?**
A: Only through the ecosystem's contribution system (if/when implemented). Independent crypto addresses trigger opt-out.

**Q: Is the detection always accurate?**
A: The scanner aims for high accuracy but may have false positives. You can appeal via GitHub issues.

**Q: What if I remove external methods after being flagged?**
A: Your app will be automatically restored to compliant status on the next scan.

**Q: Can I opt back in after opting out?**
A: Yes, simply remove external contribution methods and the next scan will mark you compliant.

The user is asking about a mechanism to detect when a developer removes the ecosystem footer (which includes the payment/contribution link). This is essentially asking: if someone uses the template but removes the attribution/contribution footer, how do we detect that and remove them from the ecosystem?

Looking at my current implementation:

1. The detection script checks for `hasEcosystemFooter` by looking for allowed patterns like `puter-ecosystem-footer`, `data-ecosystem-version`, etc.

2. If the footer is missing, the app is marked as NON-COMPLIANT because compliance requires BOTH:
   - No external contribution methods detected
   - Ecosystem footer present

3. The verification workflow runs daily and will detect this.

However, the user is asking if there's a clear mechanism for this. Let me check my implementation more carefully and potentially enhance it to make this clearer.

In my current `scan()` function:
```javascript
return {
    compliant: this.findings.length === 0 && hasEcosystemFooter,
    hasEcosystemFooter,
    externalMethodsDetected: this.findings.length > 0,
    findings: this.findings,
    summary: this.getSummary()
};
```

So `compliant` is only true if:
1. No findings (no external methods)
2. AND hasEcosystemFooter is true

This means removing the footer = non-compliant = opt-out.

But the user might want this to be more explicit and perhaps have a separate detection category for "missing footer". Let me enhance the implementation to make this clearer and add specific reporting for missing footer violations.

## 8. Control Flow Graphs

Full Control Flow Graphs for all 119 functions across 16 classes are documented in:

**[CFG.md](./CFG.md)**

### CFG Notation
- `[Bn]` = Basic Block n
- `-->` = Unconditional edge
- `--T-->` = True branch
- `--F-->` = False branch
- `--E-->` = Exception/error edge
- `(loop)` = Back edge

### System-Level Flow

```
[GitHub Template] ----deploy----> [GitHub Pages App]
                                         |
                                         v
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                  |                      |                      |
                  v                      v                      v
         [Direct Fetch]          [Tor/I2P/Lokinet]        [BitTorrent]
                  |                      |                      |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                                         |
                                         v
                              [Ecosystem Node Scanner]
                                         |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                  |                      |                      |
                  v                      v                      v
           [Footer Check]        [Pattern Scan]         [FUNDING.yml]
                  |                      |                      |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                                         |
                        +----------------+----------------+
                        |                                 |
                        v                                 v
                  [COMPLIANT]                      [VIOLATION]
                        |                                 |
                        v                                 v
              [Create Attestation]              [Create Removal Attestation]
                        |                                 |
                        +----------------+----------------+
                                         |
                                         v
                              [Sign with Ed25519]
                                         |
                                         v
                              [Add to Chain]
                                         |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                  |                      |                      |
                  v                      v                      v
           [IPFS Publish]         [BitTorrent]          [Registry Update]
                  |                      |                      |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                                         |
                                         v
                              [Directory Updated]
                                         |
                  +----------------------+----------------------+
                  |                      |                      |
                  v                      v                      v
         [Puter Browser]         [App Discovery]        [Revenue Sharing]
```

### CFG Summary by File

| File | Functions | Classes | CFG Nodes |
|------|-----------|---------|-----------|
| `detect-external-contributions.js` | 7 | 1 | ~85 |
| `ipfs-storage.js` | 20 | 3 | ~120 |
| `attestation-chain.js` | 29 | 3 | ~180 |
| `torrent-distribution.js` | 16 | 3 | ~95 |
| `privacy-layer.js` | 30 | 5 | ~150 |
| `ecosystem-node.js` | 17 | 1 | ~130 |
| **Total** | **119** | **16** | **~760** |

codeBlocks.content:
name: Verify Ecosystem Compliance

on:
  schedule:
    # Run daily at midnight UTC
    - cron: '0 0 * * *'
  workflow_dispatch:
    inputs:
      specific_app:
        description: 'Specific app URL to verify (optional)'
        required: false
        type: string

permissions:
  contents: write
  issues: write

jobs:
  verify-compliance:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        
      - name: Setup Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          
      - name: Fetch ecosystem registry
        id: fetch-registry
        run: |
          echo "Fetching registered apps from ecosystem registry..."
          
          # Create ecosystem directory if it doesn't exist
          mkdir -p ecosystem
          
          # Try to fetch existing registry, or create empty one
          if [ -f "ecosystem/registry.json" ]; then
            echo "Using existing registry"
          else
            echo '{"apps":[],"lastUpdated":"'$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")'"}' > ecosystem/registry.json
          fi
          
          # Count registered apps
          APP_COUNT=$(jq '.apps | length' ecosystem/registry.json)
          echo "app_count=$APP_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          
      - name: Run compliance verification
        id: verify
        run: |
          echo "Running compliance verification..."
          
          # Create results directory
          mkdir -p ecosystem/compliance-results
          
          # Initialize results
          echo '{"verified":[],"violations":[],"errors":[],"timestamp":"'$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")'"}' > ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
          
          # Check if we have a specific app to verify
          SPECIFIC_APP="${{ github.event.inputs.specific_app }}"
          
          if [ -n "$SPECIFIC_APP" ]; then
            echo "Verifying specific app: $SPECIFIC_APP"
            node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js "$SPECIFIC_APP" --json > /tmp/result.json 2>&1 || true
            
            # Check result
            if jq -e '.compliant == true' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
              echo "App is COMPLIANT"
              jq --arg url "$SPECIFIC_APP" '.verified += [{"url": $url, "timestamp": now | todate}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
              mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
            else
              echo "App has VIOLATIONS"
              FINDINGS=$(jq -c '.findings' /tmp/result.json 2>/dev/null || echo '[]')
              jq --arg url "$SPECIFIC_APP" --argjson findings "$FINDINGS" '.violations += [{"url": $url, "findings": $findings, "timestamp": now | todate}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
              mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
            fi
          else
            echo "Verifying all registered apps..."
            
            # Iterate through registered apps
            jq -r '.apps[].url' ecosystem/registry.json 2>/dev/null | while read -r APP_URL; do
              if [ -n "$APP_URL" ]; then
                echo "Checking: $APP_URL"
                
                # Run detection (with timeout)
                timeout 30 node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js "$APP_URL" --json > /tmp/result.json 2>&1 || true
                
                # Process result
                if jq -e '.compliant == true' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" '.verified += [{"url": $url}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                elif jq -e '.error' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
                  ERROR_MSG=$(jq -r '.error' /tmp/result.json)
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" --arg err "$ERROR_MSG" '.errors += [{"url": $url, "error": $err}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                else
                  FINDINGS=$(jq -c '.findings' /tmp/result.json 2>/dev/null || echo '[]')
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" --argjson findings "$FINDINGS" '.violations += [{"url": $url, "findings": $findings}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                fi
              fi
            done
          fi
          
          # Generate summary
          VERIFIED_COUNT=$(jq '.verified | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          VIOLATION_COUNT=$(jq '.violations | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          ERROR_COUNT=$(jq '.errors | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          
          echo "verified_count=$VERIFIED_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "violation_count=$VIOLATION_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "error_count=$ERROR_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          
      - name: Update compliance registry
        run: |
          echo "Updating compliance status in registry..."
          
          # Read violations
          VIOLATIONS=$(jq -r '.violations[].url' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json 2>/dev/null || echo "")
          
          # Update registry with compliance status
          for VIOLATION_URL in $VIOLATIONS; do
            if [ -n "$VIOLATION_URL" ]; then
              echo "Marking as non-compliant: $VIOLATION_URL"
              jq --arg url "$VIOLATION_URL" '(.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .compliant) = false | (.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .lastViolation) = (now | todate)' ecosystem/registry.json > /tmp/updated.json 2>/dev/null || true
              if [ -f /tmp/updated.json ]; then
                mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/registry.json
              fi
            fi
          done
          
          # Mark verified apps as compliant
          VERIFIED=$(jq -r '.verified[].url' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json 2>/dev/null || echo "")
          for VERIFIED_URL in $VERIFIED; do
            if [ -n "$VERIFIED_URL" ]; then
              jq --arg url "$VERIFIED_URL" '(.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .compliant) = true | (.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .lastVerified) = (now | todate)' ecosystem/registry.json > /tmp/updated.json 2>/dev/null || true
              if [ -f /tmp/updated.json ]; then
                mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/registry.json
              fi
            fi
          done
          
      - name: Create violation issues
        if: steps.verify.outputs.violation_count > 0
        uses: actions/github-script@v7
        with:
          script: |
            const fs = require('fs');
            const results = JSON.parse(fs.readFileSync('ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json', 'utf8'));
            
            for (const violation of results.violations) {
              const title = `[Compliance] External contribution method detected: ${violation.url}`;
              
              // Check if issue already exists
              const existingIssues = await github.rest.issues.listForRepo({
                owner: context.repo.owner,
                repo: context.repo.repo,
                state: 'open',
                labels: 'compliance-violation'
              });
              
              const exists = existingIssues.data.some(issue => issue.title.includes(violation.url));
              
              if (!exists) {
                const methods = violation.findings.map(f => `- ${f.method} (${f.category})`).join('\n');
                
                const body = `## Compliance Violation Detected
            
            **App URL:** ${violation.url}
            **Detection Date:** ${new Date().toISOString()}
            
            ### External Contribution Methods Found
            
            ${methods}
            
            ---
            
            ### What This Means
            
            This app has been detected using external contribution/donation methods outside of the ecosystem's streamlined approach. Per the [Exclusive Model](./EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md), this triggers an automatic opt-out from all ecosystem benefits:
            
            - Directory listing
            - Puter browser bookmarks
            - Cross-app integration
            - Revenue sharing
            - Showcase visibility
            
            ### Resolution Options
            
            1. **Remove external methods** - Remove all external donation buttons, payment links, and FUNDING.yml to restore ecosystem eligibility
            2. **Accept opt-out** - Keep external methods and forfeit ecosystem benefits
            
            ### Appeal
            
            If you believe this is a false positive, please comment on this issue with an explanation.
            
            ---
            *This issue was automatically generated by the ecosystem compliance scanner.*`;
                
                await github.rest.issues.create({
                  owner: context.repo.owner,
                  repo: context.repo.repo,
                  title: title,
                  body: body,
                  labels: ['compliance-violation', 'automated']
                });
                
                console.log(`Created issue for: ${violation.url}`);
              }
            }
            
      - name: Generate compliance report
        run: |
          echo "# Ecosystem Compliance Report" > ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "**Generated:** $(date -u +"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S UTC")" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "## Summary" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Status | Count |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "|--------|-------|" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Compliant | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.verified_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Violations | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.violation_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Errors | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.error_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          
          if [ "${{ steps.verify.outputs.violation_count }}" -gt 0 ]; then
            echo "## Violations" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
            echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
            jq -r '.violations[] | "- [\(.url)](\(.url))"' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md 2>/dev/null || true
            echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          fi
          
          echo "## Compliant Apps" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          jq -r '.verified[] | "- [\(.url)](\(.url))"' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md 2>/dev/null || echo "No apps verified yet." >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          
      - name: Commit results
        run: |
          git config --local user.email "github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
          git config --local user.name "github-actions[bot]"
          
          git add ecosystem/ || true
          git diff --staged --quiet || git commit -m "Update ecosystem compliance results [skip ci]"
          git push || true
          
      - name: Summary
        run: |
          echo "## Compliance Verification Complete" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "| Metric | Value |" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "|--------|-------|" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "| Apps Checked | ${{ steps.fetch-registry.outputs.app_count }} |" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "| Compliant | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.verified_count }} |" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "| Violations | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.violation_count }} |" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "| Errors | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.error_count }} |" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY

{"file_path": ".github/workflows/verify-ecosystem.yml", "contents": "name: Verify Ecosystem Compliance

on:
  schedule:
    # Run daily at midnight UTC
    - cron: '0 0 * * *'
  workflow_dispatch:
    inputs:
      specific_app:
        description: 'Specific app URL to verify (optional)'
        required: false
        type: string

permissions:
  contents: write
  issues: write

jobs:
  verify-compliance:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        
      - name: Setup Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          
      - name: Fetch ecosystem registry
        id: fetch-registry
        run: |
          echo "Fetching registered apps from ecosystem registry..."
          
          # Create ecosystem directory if it doesn't exist
          mkdir -p ecosystem
          
          # Try to fetch existing registry, or create empty one
          if [ -f "ecosystem/registry.json" ]; then
            echo "Using existing registry"
          else
            echo '{"apps":[],"lastUpdated":"'$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")'"}' > ecosystem/registry.json
          fi
          
          # Count registered apps
          APP_COUNT=$(jq '.apps | length' ecosystem/registry.json)
          echo "app_count=$APP_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          
      - name: Run compliance verification
        id: verify
        run: |
          echo "Running compliance verification..."
          
          # Create results directory
          mkdir -p ecosystem/compliance-results
          
          # Initialize results
          echo '{"verified":[],"violations":[],"errors":[],"timestamp":"'$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")'"}' > ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
          
          # Check if we have a specific app to verify
          SPECIFIC_APP="${{ github.event.inputs.specific_app }}"
          
          if [ -n "$SPECIFIC_APP" ]; then
            echo "Verifying specific app: $SPECIFIC_APP"
            node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js "$SPECIFIC_APP" --json > /tmp/result.json 2>&1 || true
            
            # Check result
            if jq -e '.compliant == true' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
              echo "App is COMPLIANT"
              jq --arg url "$SPECIFIC_APP" '.verified += [{"url": $url, "timestamp": now | todate}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
              mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
            else
              echo "App has VIOLATIONS"
              FINDINGS=$(jq -c '.findings' /tmp/result.json 2>/dev/null || echo '[]')
              jq --arg url "$SPECIFIC_APP" --argjson findings "$FINDINGS" '.violations += [{"url": $url, "findings": $findings, "timestamp": now | todate}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
              mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
            fi
          else
            echo "Verifying all registered apps..."
            
            # Iterate through registered apps
            jq -r '.apps[].url' ecosystem/registry.json 2>/dev/null | while read -r APP_URL; do
              if [ -n "$APP_URL" ]; then
                echo "Checking: $APP_URL"
                
                # Run detection (with timeout)
                timeout 30 node scripts/detect-external-contributions.js "$APP_URL" --json > /tmp/result.json 2>&1 || true
                
                # Process result
                if jq -e '.compliant == true' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" '.verified += [{"url": $url}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                elif jq -e '.error' /tmp/result.json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
                  ERROR_MSG=$(jq -r '.error' /tmp/result.json)
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" --arg err "$ERROR_MSG" '.errors += [{"url": $url, "error": $err}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                else
                  FINDINGS=$(jq -c '.findings' /tmp/result.json 2>/dev/null || echo '[]')
                  jq --arg url "$APP_URL" --argjson findings "$FINDINGS" '.violations += [{"url": $url, "findings": $findings}]' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json > /tmp/updated.json
                  mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json
                fi
              fi
            done
          fi
          
          # Generate summary
          VERIFIED_COUNT=$(jq '.verified | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          VIOLATION_COUNT=$(jq '.violations | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          ERROR_COUNT=$(jq '.errors | length' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json)
          
          echo "verified_count=$VERIFIED_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "violation_count=$VIOLATION_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "error_count=$ERROR_COUNT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          
      - name: Update compliance registry
        run: |
          echo "Updating compliance status in registry..."
          
          # Read violations
          VIOLATIONS=$(jq -r '.violations[].url' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json 2>/dev/null || echo "")
          
          # Update registry with compliance status
          for VIOLATION_URL in $VIOLATIONS; do
            if [ -n "$VIOLATION_URL" ]; then
              echo "Marking as non-compliant: $VIOLATION_URL"
              jq --arg url "$VIOLATION_URL" '(.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .compliant) = false | (.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .lastViolation) = (now | todate)' ecosystem/registry.json > /tmp/updated.json 2>/dev/null || true
              if [ -f /tmp/updated.json ]; then
                mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/registry.json
              fi
            fi
          done
          
          # Mark verified apps as compliant
          VERIFIED=$(jq -r '.verified[].url' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json 2>/dev/null || echo "")
          for VERIFIED_URL in $VERIFIED; do
            if [ -n "$VERIFIED_URL" ]; then
              jq --arg url "$VERIFIED_URL" '(.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .compliant) = true | (.apps[] | select(.url == $url) | .lastVerified) = (now | todate)' ecosystem/registry.json > /tmp/updated.json 2>/dev/null || true
              if [ -f /tmp/updated.json ]; then
                mv /tmp/updated.json ecosystem/registry.json
              fi
            fi
          done
          
      - name: Create violation issues
        if: steps.verify.outputs.violation_count > 0
        uses: actions/github-script@v7
        with:
          script: |
            const fs = require('fs');
            const results = JSON.parse(fs.readFileSync('ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json', 'utf8'));
            
            for (const violation of results.violations) {
              const title = `[Compliance] External contribution method detected: ${violation.url}`;
              
              // Check if issue already exists
              const existingIssues = await github.rest.issues.listForRepo({
                owner: context.repo.owner,
                repo: context.repo.repo,
                state: 'open',
                labels: 'compliance-violation'
              });
              
              const exists = existingIssues.data.some(issue => issue.title.includes(violation.url));
              
              if (!exists) {
                const methods = violation.findings.map(f => `- ${f.method} (${f.category})`).join('\n');
                
                const body = `## Compliance Violation Detected
            
            **App URL:** ${violation.url}
            **Detection Date:** ${new Date().toISOString()}
            
            ### External Contribution Methods Found
            
            ${methods}
            
            ---
            
            ### What This Means
            
            This app has been detected using external contribution/donation methods outside of the ecosystem's streamlined approach. Per the [Exclusive Model](./EXCLUSIVE_MODEL.md), this triggers an automatic opt-out from all ecosystem benefits:
            
            - Directory listing
            - Puter browser bookmarks
            - Cross-app integration
            - Revenue sharing
            - Showcase visibility
            
            ### Resolution Options
            
            1. **Remove external methods** - Remove all external donation buttons, payment links, and FUNDING.yml to restore ecosystem eligibility
            2. **Accept opt-out** - Keep external methods and forfeit ecosystem benefits
            
            ### Appeal
            
            If you believe this is a false positive, please comment on this issue with an explanation.
            
            ---
            *This issue was automatically generated by the ecosystem compliance scanner.*`;
                
                await github.rest.issues.create({
                  owner: context.repo.owner,
                  repo: context.repo.repo,
                  title: title,
                  body: body,
                  labels: ['compliance-violation', 'automated']
                });
                
                console.log(`Created issue for: ${violation.url}`);
              }
            }
            
      - name: Generate compliance report
        run: |
          echo "# Ecosystem Compliance Report" > ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "**Generated:** $(date -u +"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S UTC")" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "## Summary" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Status | Count |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "|--------|-------|" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Compliant | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.verified_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Violations | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.violation_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "| Errors | ${{ steps.verify.outputs.error_count }} |" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          
          if [ "${{ steps.verify.outputs.violation_count }}" -gt 0 ]; then
            echo "## Violations" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
            echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
            jq -r '.violations[] | "- [\(.url)](\(.url))"' ecosystem/compliance-results/latest.json >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md 2>/dev/null || true
            echo "" >> ecosystem/COMPLIANCE_REPORT.md
          fi
